pageMeta.description: Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. They exacerbate the natural greenhouse effect, leading to temperature changes and other disruption of the earth's climate. Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

content.value: Climate change adaptation - Impacts and risks

Climate change impacts are especially acute in the LAC region where economic and social vulnerability are compounded by a very close social and economic relationship with the environment. 13 of the 50 countries most affected by climate change worldwide are in the region.

Increasing temperatures combined with extreme rainfall events pose significant risks for countries dependent on agriculture production. As rainfall becomes less predictable, severe levels of drought are also becoming more frequent. Soil moisture on croplands has decreased significantly, with countries such as Peru, Chile, Argentina and Mexico experiencing up to a 40% decrease. These trends heavily impact croplands and lead to a decrease in agricultural productivity, as well as concerns over food security.

Forest areas potentially exposed to wildfires is very large (32%), presenting an imminent risk to populations and ecosystems. In some countries such as Jamaica, Paraguay, Mexico and El Salvador, over 70% of the forest area is exposed to wildfires.

The ocean is a crucial shared resource of the region, with all but two countries sharing coastlines with the Atlantic Ocean, the Pacific Ocean or the Caribbean Sea. Twenty-three of the 33 LAC countries have more marine than terrestrial territory, for 18 of which the maritime area exceeds 75% of total territory.

The region is close to reaching the Convention on Biological Diversity target of designating at least 30% of Earth’s land and sea areas as protected for conservation by 2030, with an average of 29.7% of land designated as terrestrial protected areas, and 22% of Exclusive Economic Zones as marine protected areas.

Climate change generates significant impacts on the environment, the economy and human welfare. It threatens ecosystems and biodiversity, affects water resources, human settlements and the frequency and scale of extreme weather events, with significant effects on food security, human well-being, socio-economic activities and economic output. Climate change impacts can generate considerable losses from both extreme events (such as hurricanes) and slow onset events (such as the sea level rise), and contribute to increased socio-economic inequalities.

Some impacts will gradually affect economic processes, such as those associated with rising temperatures, while others may be more acute and periodic such as the increased intensity and frequency of climate-related hazards. Climate-related hazards put populations and economic assets at riskthrough increased frequency and intensity of hot temperature extremes, marine heatwaves, heavy precipitation, droughts, intense tropical cyclones and reductions in Arctic Sea ice, snow cover and permafrost. Further threats include wildfires, coastal floods, and sea-level rises
Latin American Economic Outlook 2022: Towards a Green and Just Transition

The loss of biodiversity is a key concern nationally and globally. It reduces ecosystem resilience and increases vulnerability to threats such as the negative impacts of climate change. Changes in climate and weather conditions also affect biodiversity. Pressures on biodiversity can be physical (e.g. habitat alteration and fragmentation through changes in land use and sea use, and changes in land cover, over-exploitation of natural resources), chemical (toxic contamination, acidification, oil spills, other pollution from human activities) or biological (e.g. alteration of population dynamics and species structure through invasive alien species or the commercial use of wildlife resources).

The main challenges are to adapt to and manage current and future risks from climate change, protect vulnerable populations and enable the restoration of environmental and other assets that have been lost or degraded. This implies:
Integrating adaptation concerns into economic and sectoral policies, and effectively integrating climate and biodiversity policies.
that build bridges between nationally determined contributions (NDCs) and the GBF’s National Biodiversity Strategies and Action Plans (NBSAPs)

] to adapt to or reduce climate change risks while ensuring human well-being and biodiversity benefits, including by restoring natural systems to enhance or recover ecosystem services associated with climate change processes, and strengthening the degree of protection of species, habitats, and terrestrial, marine and other aquatic ecosystems, including oceans..

Putting in place ambitious policy mixes (regulatory approaches, economic instruments, and other information and voluntary approaches) that encourage investments in products and natural assets that help reduce the impact of climate change and build resilient infrastructures.

Reforming and removing environmentally harmful subsidies and strengthening the role of biodiversity-relevant taxes, fees and charges, as well as other economic instruments such as payments for ecosystem services, biodiversity offsets and tradable permits (such as transferable quotas for fisheries).

In the LAC region, important challenges are to help coastal communities adapt to the risks stemming from rising sea levels, extreme weather events and flooding. As appropriate for local contexts, countries should engage with and protect those most vulnerable, adopt long-term plans for coastal areas which take future changes into account, implement maritime spatial planning in coherence with coastal zone management, and protect existing coastal ecosystems that serve as natural buffers.
Progress can be measured against domestic objectives and international commitments such as those under the UNFCCC PA and the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) ……

Conference of the Parties (COP15) in Montreal from 7-19 December 2022, where the Post-2020 Biodiversity Framework was adopted, comprising 21 targets and 10 milestones for 2030. Notable targets include the designation of at least 30% of Earth’s land and sea areas as protected for conservation; the reduction of nutrients lost to the environment by at least half, pesticides by at least two thirds, and the elimination of discharge of plastic waste; and the reduction of harmful incentives for biodiversity by at least 50 billion USD per year. Positively, several Latin American and Caribbean countries comply with the protected areas target (

Conference of the Parties (COP27) held in Sharm el-Sheikh from 6-18 November 2022 closed with the establishment of a Loss and Damage fund for countries vulnerable to arising from droughts, floods, rising sea level and other disasters attributed to climate change being particularly relevant for the Caribbean islands. At the time of writing, no decision has been reached on the sources or recipients of said funding.
The indicators presented in this section describe selected climate hazards and related exposure levels, and the inter-connection with biodiversity. The build on data available for most LAC countries.
To track the most significant impacts of climate change, the OECD has developed a new set of indicators to monitor climate-related hazards and exposure to these hazards
Demographic Observatory Latin America and the Caribbean 2022

. The indicator set is based on the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s (IPCC) conceptualisation of climate risk, which considers climate-related hazard, exposure, and vulnerability as the key dimensions of disaster risk (
). The indicators presented are based on this new data set.

A climate-related hazard is a “potentially damaging climate-related physical event, phenomenon, or human activity that may cause the loss of life or injury, property damage, social and economic disruption or environmental degradation”
[25] IPCC (2022), “Climate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability”,

. Climate-related hazards can include both sudden onset hazards (i.e., event-driven hazards such as heatwaves or cyclones) and slow onset hazards (i.e., long-term changes in the mean and variability of climate patterns such as mean precipitation or temperature).

The following indicators can support LAC countries to understand the impact of climate-related hazards by assessing the exposure of people and assets to these hazards. It focuses on seven hazard types: (1) extreme temperature, (2) extreme precipitation, (3) drought, (4) wildfire, (5) wind threats, (6) river flooding and (7) coastal flooding. These are key natural hazards, influenced by climate change, with important impacts on people and assets
Demographic Observatory Latin America and the Caribbean 2022

presents a summary of the sum of hazards identified for a specific geographical area. It can be considered as a map of climate-related hazard “hotspots” where countries need to be concerned with developing integral adaptation and recovery and emergency actions, since they represent areas potentially affected by critical or extreme events.

Climate change impacts are especially acute in the LAC region where economic and social vulnerability are compounded by a very close social and economic relationship with the environment. 13 of the 50 countries most affected by climate change worldwide are in the region
Monitoring exposure to climate-related hazards: Indicator methodology and key results

. The average quantity of extreme climate‑related weather events in LAC increased in most countries between 2001 and 2022 compared to the previous two decades, on average increasing from 0.55 annual extreme weather events (resulting in 100 000 or more people affected, or 1 000 or more deaths, or at least 2% of GDP in estimated economic damages) during the period 1980-2000 to 0.89 during the period 2001-2022. Around 18% of the 11,072 climate‑related extreme weather events registered worldwide between 1970 and 2019 occurred in LAC
Climate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability

. Warming temperatures, extreme precipitation events leading to floods, landslides and droughts, sea level rise, coastal erosion, ocean and lake acidification resulting in coral bleaching, and storm surges are expected to increase in frequency and severity, with adverse socio‑economic consequences on the region
. An average of 17 hurricanes per year and 23 category‑5 hurricanes were recorded between 2000 and 2019, mostly affecting Caribbean and Central American countries

Over the past decades, population exposure in the LAC region to heat stress has increased significantly.The average temperature recorded for the period 1991‑2020 in LAC is more than 1°C higher than the average for the period 1901‑30

In 2021, on average, 9% of the population in LAC countries was exposed to more than 2 weeks of hot summer days (measured as a daily maximum temperature being above 35 °C), a 3% increase since 1979. This average, however, masks important national variations. Countries dependent on agriculture production such as in the LAC region, are more vulnerable to increasing temperatures combined with extreme rainfall events. Many LAC countries are experiencing an increase in extreme precipitation, a hazard that can trigger the destruction of crops, landslides, or other extreme events. On average, LAC countries have 6.9% of their cropland exposed to more than one week of extreme precipitation (when precipitation exceeds the 99th percentile of the reference period 1981-2010), an increase from 5.2% since 2000. For some countries have seen a more dramatic change, such as Suriname, Guyana, and Trinidad and Tobago that have 64%, 58%, and 28%, of their cropland exposed to more than one week of extreme precipitation. Across the LAC countries there has been a significant decrease in soil moisture on croplands over the last four decades, decreasing by around 2.5%, on average, between the reference period 1981-2010 and 2017-2021. The countries most affected during this period include Paraguay, Argentina, and Brazil, which experienced a decline in cropland soil moisture of more than 8.6%, 7.7%, and 5.8%, respectively (

For example, soil moisture in South America has decreased by 3.7% during this period, while countries such as Peru, Chile and Argentina experienced up to a 40% decrease in soil moisture. In some countries such as Jamaica, Paraguay, Mexico and El Salvador, over 70% of the forested area is exposed to wildfires. The shares are smaller in Brazil and Venezuela (46% and 40% respectively), but nevertheless represent large areas due to the size of these countries (over 2.2 million km

River flooding is a climate-related hazard that has generated increasing concern globally. Due to the type of ecosystem and the location of most populations, river flooding is not a major concern in the LAC region. It is estimated that on average, 5% of the population is affected in the LAC region. This varies across the subregions, with South American, Central American and the Caribbean countries having, respectively 11.9%, 3.3%, and 0.1% of their population exposed. The increasing cost of climate-related hazards in LAC
One study shows global GDP could be reduced by as much as 4% in 2050 due to climate change and that lower-income and lower‑middle income countries are more likely face economic losses
. The costs from natural disasters alone are estimated at USD 280 billion in 2021, representing approximately 0.29% of global GDP
Latin America and the Caribbean: Natural Disasters 2000-2019

For example, in the Dominican Republic, the heavy rains of 2016 generated severe economic losses in crops such as plantain, cassava and sweet potato. During the hurricane season of 2017, an estimated loss of USD 52 million was recorded due to lower touristic activity. In the case of Haiti and Puerto Rico, two of the three most affected countries in the world between 1999 and 2018, annual GDP losses reached 2.38% and 3.76%, respectively

Similar economic costs can be caused by the concentration of multiple non‑extreme events in a short period, especially when there are conditions of high exposure and vulnerability in the country. Many countries in LAC are experiencing a fall in agricultural productivity and tourism, as well as climate‑driven migration and high reconstruction costs after natural disasters.

Natural disasters increase expenditures and thus have direct impacts on fiscal deficits and public revenues, affecting the long-term fiscal sustainability of governments. On average, a natural disaster results in costs of 0.8% and 1.1% of GDP, for lower middle‑income and low‑income countries respectively

. For many LAC countries the fiscal capacity to deal with the increasing impacts of climate change is limited. On average, a natural disaster results in an increase in the fiscal deficit of 0.3% of GDP for upper‑middle‑income countries, 0.8% for lower‑middle‑income countries and 0.9% for low‑income countries

For all the costs of extreme events, the costs of inaction may be even higher. In the case of the Caribbean, the annual cost of inaction to deal with the effects of sea level rise is estimated to reach USD 22 billion per year by 2050 (10% of GDP) and USD 46 billion by 2100 (22% of GDP)

. If environmental degradation is not addressed soon, LAC governments will have to add the costs of climate change to those of social vulnerability that could have unprecedented economic and social consequences.

Natural climate variability and human-caused climate change increase risks attributed to climate-related hazards, influencing the frequency, intensity, extent and duration of extreme weather and climate events. Climate-related hazard, exposure and vulnerability are key dimensions of disaster risk. Measuring all dimensions that encompass risk is difficult because of data limitations, particularly on a global scale. For example, there are no commonly used data sources for assessing vulnerability globally.

The indicators presented are a selection of a broader set of indicators observed climate-related hazards developed by Maes et al. (2022) the indicators are on data from a number of official sources such as the Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), among others. For a detailed discussion see Maes et al. (2022). All regional averages presented here are simple, non-weighted averages over the countries in the LAC region. They therefore do not consider differences in area or population and represent the exposure of an average LAC country to natural hazards, but not the actual share of land or population of the region that is exposed.
The environmental changes driven by climate change are disturbing natural habitats and species in many ways, adding
to the threats to biodiversity from human activities.
This in turn further intensifies the effects of climate change, which cause biodiversity loss.
Biodiversity and ecosystem services are integral elements of the natural capital of Latin America and the Caribbean, and the loss of biodiversity is a key concern
Costa Rica’s Forest Conservation Pays Off

. Many economic activities rely on the quality of the region’s ecosystems. Beautiful landscapes and beaches with a mild sunny climate are the basis of an important tourism industry, particularly in Central America and the Caribbean. The Humboldt current along the south Pacific brings nutrient-rich waters to the coast, creating a rich and diverse fishery industry in Chile and Peru. Forestry is also a major economic activity of the Amazon River basin. Many high-value tree species, such as mahogany and rosewood, are native to the rainforest. Chile is an important exporter of wood chips, plywood and paper pulp.

LAC’s rich natural environment is an opportunity for economic development but also generates considerable challenges, risks, and vulnerabilities. Land use change, deforestation, increased nutrient pollution from intensive agricultural practices, and mining production are some of the main pressures on the environment caused by the exploitation of these natural resources. Retreating glaciers, bleaching coral reefs and loss of ecosystem services undermine the ability of ecosystems to provide a shield against growing climate‑related risks and creates additional vulnerabilities. Threats against the Amazon rainforest from fires and forest degradation are projected to continue worsening in frequency and intensity
The Outlook for Agriculture and Rural Development in the Americas: A Perspective on Latin America and the Caribbean 2021-2022

. Volcanic mountains in Central America increase the risk of disasters but also contribute to rich and fertile soils. The South American continent is endowed with important mineral resources, it contains about one fifth of the world’s iron ore reserves, more than one quarter of the world’s copper reserves (mostly in Peru and Chile), as well as tin, lead and zinc (found mostly in Bolivia, Brazil, Peru and Argentina). There are also important oil reserves in Colombia, Ecuador and, notably, Venezuela, and immense gas reserves in Bolivia.

Biodiversity loss reduces ecosystem resilience and increases vulnerability to threats such as the negative impacts of climate change. The LAC region is home to major ecosystems that are directly under pressure because of climate change and other environmental impacts. The loss of biodiversity is a key concern in Latin America and the Caribbean, declining at twice the rate observed across OECD countries
The Outlook for Agriculture and Rural Development in the Americas: A Perspective on Latin America and the Caribbean 2021-2022
. While Chile, Ecuador and Mexico experience the largest declines, every country in the region is considered to have “high‑risk” rates of decline

Protected areas are legally designated areas for the protection and maintenance of biological diversity and of natural resources and the associated cultural resources, managed through administrative or other effective means. Although national classifications differ, The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has developed an internationally agreed definition of protected areas, which classify them as nature reserves and wilderness areas, national parks, natural monuments, habitat or species management areas, protected landscapes or seascapes, and protected areas with sustainable use of natural resources. The region counts with over 7 million km
of terrestrial protected areas and over 4 million km
of marine protected areas, representing 35% of total land area of countries of the region, and 22% of Exclusive Economic Zones, respectively.

Conference of the Parties of the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) adopted a target to conserve and manage 30% areas (terrestrial, inland water, and coastal and marine) by 2030. The LAC region as a whole is close to reaching this target, with an average of 29.7% of land designated as terrestrial protected areas in 2021 (

). This share has increased steadily over the past few decades from an average of under 3% across the region in 1970, to under 5% in 1980. Countries driving the trend include Belize, Bolivia, Brazil, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Panama, Trinidad and Tobago and Venezuela, all of which have surpassed the CBD 2030 target. Nevertheless, most of these countries rely on the least stringent designation purposes of protected areas (such as protected landscapes) rather than strict nature reserves, national parks and wilderness areas.

Marine protected areas are less commonly designated throughout the LAC region, with 5 countries reaching the CBD 2030 target. The share of marine protected areas across the region represents about 20% of the exclusive economic zone (EEZ). It has increased slowly from 1960, remaining below 3% of the EEZ until 2010, and below 5% until 2016. Only 10 territories have strict nature reserves, national parks or wilderness areas.

Terrestrial protected areas as percentage of total land: protected areas are areas of land especially dedicated to the protection and maintenance of biological diversity and of natural and associated cultural resources, and managed through legal or other effective means. The data refer to the World Conservation Union (IUCN) management categories I-VI. National classifications may differ.

Note: the the Global Biodiversity Framework establishes the “30x30” conservation target, calling for 30% of the earth’s land and sea to be conserved through the establishment of protected areas and other area-based conservation measures.
Source: OECD, “Biodiversity: Protected areas”, OECD Environment Statistics (database),

Marine protected areas as percentage of exclusive economic zone (EEZ): protected areas are areas of sea especially dedicated to the protection and maintenance of biological diversity and of natural and associated cultural resources, and managed through legal or other effective means. The data refer to the World Conservation Union (IUCN) management categories I-VI. National classifications may differ.

Note: the the Global Biodiversity Framework establishes the “30x30” conservation target, calling for 30% of the earth’s land and sea to be conserved through the establishment of protected areas and other area-based conservation measures.
Source: OECD, “Biodiversity: Protected areas”, OECD Environment Statistics (database),

Data on protected areas is available for most LAC countries. The definitions, although harmonised by the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, may vary among countries. The extent, and management types, of terrestrial and marine protected areas can indicate countries’ efforts to safeguard habitats and species as well as landscapes shaped by human-environment interactions that are valued for cultural or other reasons. Protected areas are not always representative of national biodiversity or sufficiently connected. Indicators on the extent of protected areas do not reflect the effectiveness of the management of these areas.
